CompTIA Network+ Video Mentor Configuring an L2TP-Based VPN

David Prowse, creator of CompTIA Network+ Video Mentor,shows you how.

In this screencast and ensuing post, Ill show how to configure a Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol (L2TP) connection on the server side (Windows Server 2003) and client side (Windows XP Pro). The video and step-by-step write-up are broken into six methods:

Step 1: Install a Certificate Authority on the server.
Step two: Configure the Certificate Authority (CA) on the server.
Step 3: Configure MS-CHAP on the client.
Step 4: Configure L2TP and IPsec on the client.
Step 5: Install a certificate on the client.
Step 6: Making the new VPN connection.

This screencast assumes that you just have IIS operating on the server, you know tips on how to setup a standard VPN, and you've a VPN server running. For more specifics on tips on how to setup a simple VPN, see my internet site. (Totally free registration essential.).

Step 1: Install a Certificate Authority on the Server

Even if your client is already setup to make L2TP connections (see Step 4 for much more), and you have a standard VPN server operating, you would get a 781 error when attempting to connect. This really is considering that your client demands an encryption certificate. The client ought to get that certificate from the server (or some other authority). Lets install and configure the Certificate Authority on the Windows Server 2003 pc now in order that it can dispense certificates to customers.

Go to the Windows Server 2003 computer.
Click the Start out button and select Control Panel.
Launch Add/Remove Programs.
Pick Add/Remove Windows Components.
Click the Certificate Services check box to choose it. A pop-up window opens; click Yes.
Click Subsequent.
When asked you what kind of Certificate Authority you'll be installing, select the default option, Enterprise root CA, as shown in Figure 1. Then click Subsequent.

Figure 1 The Certificate Authority screen.
Within the Standard Name for this CA field, type test. Leave the rest with the details as-is, and click Subsequent.
Leave the Certificate Database Settings window as-is and click Next.
A pop-up window may possibly ask you about IIS, which desires to be stopped through the installation from the CA. Click OK. The installation from the CA will begin.
In case you are asked for the CD, you may get the essential information from X:i386 (where X could be the letter of your disc drive). This may be from the Windows Server 2003 disc, the Service Pack disc, or the Server 2003 disc with slipstreamed service packit depends upon your setup.

NOTE

If IIS isn't but installed, Server 2003 will warn you that Certificate Services Web Enrollment Help will not operate till IIS is installed. Click OK for this message and make sure to install IIS prior to continuing with this lab. This is often completed from Add/Remove Windows Components > Application Server > Net Knowledge Services (IIS). IIS might be installed simultaneously with Certificate Services.
Click Finish. The Certificate Authority is now installed. You must see it within your Administrative Tools. A restart will not be typically crucial, but might be an excellent idea, particularly if you have a great deal of other services operating on the server.
